description: From Middle English gleman, gleoman, from Old English glēomann, glīġman, corresponding to glee (“music; minstrelsy; entertainment”) +‎ man. Cognate with Scots gle-man, gleman (“gleeman, minstrel”).

entries.meaning: (historical) A professional singer, bard, or other entertainer.
examples: The ancient Celts carefully distinguished the poet, who was originally a priest and judge as well and whose person was sacrosanct, from the mere gleeman.
